importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the third week of the ongoing government shutdown, highlighting the prolonged impact on federal workers and public services.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown has lasted for more than a week and is now in its third week, showing the extended duration and increasing strain on federal employees and supporting services.

keyTakeAways: Over 1.4 million federal employees have been furloughed or are working without pay due to the government shutdown.
A food bank event in Landover, Maryland, served more than 370 households — more than double the expected number — indicating widespread need among federal workers.
Federal workers such as Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams report financial hardship, with rent due and no recent paychecks, showing the personal impact of the shutdown.
The event required federal employees to show a work ID, underscoring both the scale of the workforce affected and the institutional effort to provide relief.

GOP Sen. Ron Johnson proposed a bill that would only pay federal workers who are continuing to work, while Democrats advocate for full pay for all federal workers, revealing a political divide on the issue.

Pamelia Carter, a federal employee with 38 years of experience in the Department of Agriculture, observed a significant spike in demand, stating that this event is 'mind-boggling' and unprecedented in scope.
The Capital Area Food Bank, in partnership with No Limits Outreach Ministries, organized the food distribution event, showing the role of civil society in addressing the crisis.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the third week of a prolonged government shutdown, over 1.4 million federal workers have been furloughed or are working without pay, leading to severe financial strain. A food bank event in Landover, Maryland, organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries, served more than 370 households — far exceeding expectations — highlighting the widespread need among federal workers. Workers like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams describe how their jobs no longer offer financial security, with rent due and no recent paychecks. Political debate continues, with GOP Sen. Ron Johnson proposing to pay only those working during the shutdown, while Democrats advocate for full pay. The event, which required federal employees to show work IDs, underscores both the scale of the crisis and the role of civil society in providing essential support.
title: Federal workers form line down the block for food pantry as shutdown hits third-week mark
